question: This number is squared in the solution to the Basel problem. One experiment to calculate this number exploits the Buffon's needle problem. Archimedes approximated this number, the number of radians in 180 degrees, by bounding it by the perimeters of 96-sided polygons, finding that it is less than 22 over 7. Give this ratio of a circle's circumference and diameter, an irrational number approximately equal to 3.14.

This Formula One driver, known for his qualifying prowess and his ability to extract the maximum performance from his car, achieved his first Formula One victory at the 2019 Belgian Grand Prix. He drives for Scuderia Ferrari, one of the most iconic and successful teams in Formula One history. He is a member of the Ferrari Driver Academy, a program that develops young racing talent. Who is this racing driver, hailing from Monaco?

After this man made his brother Joseph an unpopular King of Spain, he had to fight the Peninsular War to defend Joseph's rule. This man forced the Treaty of Pressburg, which gave this man large amounts of land from the Austrian Empire. This man beat the Third Coalition at the Battle of Austerlitz in 1805, two months after his navy lost at Trafalgar. Name this emperor who was exiled to Saint Helena in 1815 after his French army was defeated at Waterloo.

This holiday was celebrated on Friday, March 14 in India. This Hindu spring festival, also known as the "Festival of Colors," is celebrated with vibrant displays of colored powder and water, symbolizing the arrival of spring and the victory of good over evil. Its origins are rooted in Hindu mythology, with various stories associated with the festival, including the legend of Holika and Prahlad. The festivities typically include music, dancing, and the sharing of sweets. What is the name of this joyous festival, a major celebration in India and Nepal?

This nation is home to the city of Mariupol, which is located on the Sea of Azov. The Pripyat River flows into Belarus in the north and then back into this country, which is home to most of the Dnieper River. In July 2015, Dmitry Medvedev said that this nation's southernmost section, called Crimea, had been fully integrated with Russia. Name this Eastern European nation with capital at Kiev.

This author wrote of a character who was "more brave than me:more blond than you." That "conscientious object-or" had a "heart that recoiled at war." This man wrote the poem "maggie and milly and molly and may," which has almost no capital letters, and described a man who "sang his didn't and danced his did." "anyone lived in a pretty how town" is by what American poet known for his strange punctuation and capitalization?

This musician's 1959 album, "Kind of Blue," considered one of the greatest jazz albums of all time, popularized modal jazz, a style characterized by its improvisational freedom and harmonic ambiguity. His innovative use of the Harmon mute, which he often placed close to the microphone, created a distinctive and intimate sound. He was a key figure in the development of bebop, cool jazz, hard bop, and modal jazz, constantly pushing the boundaries of the genre. Who is this trumpeter and composer, known for his influential contributions to jazz music?

A followup to this Supreme Court case said that the ruling should be carried out "with all deliberate speed." This Supreme Court case overturned the Plessy v. Ferguson decision. The majority opinion in this case stated that "separate educational facilities are inherently unequal." The organization that lost this case was based in Topeka, Kansas. Name this 1954 Supreme Court case that worked to desegregate schools.
answers: Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka, Kansas

question: This animated film's iconic characters, Woody and Buzz Lightyear, have become beloved figures in popular culture, representing friendship and adventure. Its groundbreaking use of computer-generated imagery (CGI) revolutionized animation and paved the way for future animated films. Its story, which explores themes of growing up and the importance of imagination, has resonated with audiences of all ages. What is the name of this 1995 Pixar film, the first full-length computer-animated feature film?

This religious action is described in Paul's letter to the Ephesians as a result of having "one lord" and"one faith." The son of Elizabeth, John, saw the Holy Spirit descend "like a dove" onto Jesus during this ritual in the Jordan River. In Catholicism, this action is typically performed on infants and in Eastern Orthodoxy, it can be performed through full immersion. Name this Christian ritual, also called "christening," in which a person is inducted into the church by being blessed with water.

This Formula 1 driver, known for his consistent performances and his popular presence on social media, achieved his first Formula 1 victory at the 2024 Miami Grand Prix. He drives for McLaren, a historic team in Formula 1. He is often seen as a rising star in the sport. Who is this British driver?

President Donald Trump has threatened to cut the staff of this agency which is associated with a US national deadline on April 15. This agency's primary function is to enforce the tax laws of the United States, collecting taxes and providing assistance to taxpayers. Its origins can be traced back to the Civil War, when it was established to help finance the war effort. The agency is responsible for processing millions of tax returns each year, a complex task that involves verifying information and ensuring compliance. What is the name of this bureau of the Department of the Treasury?

This state's tallest peak is Mount Elbert, and its official flower, the blue columbine, was discovered during the first ascent of a mountain discovered by Zebulon Pike. Over 50 "fourteeners," or mountains over 14,000 feet tall, are found in what "Mile High" state in the Rockies, with capital Denver?

An equation named for Konstantin Tsiolkovsky is used to calculate the motion of these machines, because they get lighter through fuel loss as they travel. Robert Goddard and Werner von Braun are scientists best known for their work with these machines, which may be comprised of multiple stages which fall off as they fly. What vehicles such as Saturn V and Falcon 9 are used to launch into space?

This president's policies were frequently blocked by the "Four Horsemen," a conservative block of the Supreme Court, and he failed in a controversial attempt to "pack" more justices on the Court. This man used bank holidays and new agencies like the Tennessee Valley Authority and WPA to fight the Great Depression. Name this president who expanded the federal government through his New Deal policies while suffering from polio.

A holder of this title controversially pushed his people away from polytheism in favor of a solar god worshiped at Amarna. Lord Carnavon funded Howard Carter's 1922 expedition to discover the burial grounds of one of these people at Luxor; that mission found a sarcophagus containing a solid gold funerary mask and mummified remains. Name this title given to Akenhaten, King Tut, and other ancient Egyptian rulers.

Following the 2003 Goodridge case, Massachusetts became the first state to grant the right to perform this action, which California took away in Proposition 8. After the case Obergefell v. Hodges legalized this action nationwide by striking down the Defense of Marriage Act, the White House was temporarily lit up with rainbow pride colors. Name this action that might involve two men becoming husbands.

This footballer's philosophy, known as "Total Football," revolutionized the sport with its fluid formations and emphasis on positional interchangeability. He won the Ballon d'Or three times and was a key player for both Ajax and Barcelona, two clubs that are synonymous with his style of play. He also managed both Ajax and Barcelona, continuing to implement his tactical vision and shaping the future of football. Who is this Dutch football legend, known for his technical brilliance and his profound influence on the game?

This director's 2019 film, "Parasite," made history by becoming the first non-English language film to win the Academy Award for Best Picture. His films often blend genres, incorporating elements of thriller, comedy, and social commentary, exploring themes of class inequality and social injustice. He has directed acclaimed films such as "Memories of Murder," "The Host," and "Snowpiercer," showcasing his versatility and his ability to create compelling and thought-provoking cinema. Who is this South Korean filmmaker, known for his masterful storytelling and his unique cinematic vision?

This event will occur in the Northern Hemisphere on March 20, 2025. This astronomical event, marking the beginning of spring occurs when the Sun crosses the celestial equator, resulting in roughly equal lengths of day and night. It has been celebrated in various cultures throughout history with festivals and rituals symbolizing renewal and rebirth. Its date varies slightly each year due to the Earth's elliptical orbit and axial tilt. What is the name of this event, a significant point in the Earth's annual cycle around the Sun?

When preceded by the German root "zwitter" [z'vitter], this term describes a molecule that is simultaneously dipolar. Bases are classified as strong or weak by their ability to completely dissociate into these things; for example, lye breaks apart into hydroxide molecules and sodium atoms. Give this term for chemicals that have lost or gained electrons and thus have a positive or negative electric charge.

During this battle, the Chateau of Hougoumont was besieged. British troops in this battle protected themselves from artillery fire by lying down on the reverse slope of La Haye Sainte. British infantry squares repeatedly turned back cavalry led by Marshal Ney at this battle. This battle concluded when the British were relieved by a Prussian Army under General von Blucher. Name this 1815 battle in Belgium in which the Duke of Wellington defeated Napoleon.

This region is home to the American-operated McMurdo Station on its Ross Island. This region is separated from one continent's southern tip, Cape Horn, by the Drake Passage. The Adelie and emperor species of a certain bird only live in this region. Penguins live on this continent, which is home to the South Pole. Name this least populous and coldest continent in the world.

In this novel, "with sheets" is added to one of the Seven Commandments, which are written on a wall after Jones and his men are defeated at the Battle of the Cowshed. In this novel, Old Major teaches the song"Beasts of England," Boxer repeats "Napoleon is always right," and Snowball teaches the motto "Four legs good! Two legs bad!" to a group of sheep. A Marxist revolution is led by pigs in what George Orwell novel?

The former president of the this nation, Rodrigo Duterte, was arrested on the basis of an International Criminal Court warrant charging him with crimes against humanity during his national war on drugs. This Southeast Asian country, known for its stunning beaches and vibrant coral reefs, is comprised of over 7,000 islands, making it an archipelago. Its capital city, Manila, is a bustling metropolis with a rich history and a mix of modern and colonial architecture. It is the world's leading exporter of coconut oil and a major producer of rice and other agricultural products. What is this country known for its iconic jeepney transportation?

This singer-songwriter's introspective lyrics and gentle acoustic guitar style, often exploring themes of personal struggles and emotional healing, helped define the singer-songwriter movement of the 1970s. His album "Sweet Baby James," released in 1970, catapulted him to fame and featured his signature song of the same name. His distinctive voice and his fingerpicking technique have become instantly recognizable, earning him a dedicated fanbase. Who is this musician, known for his hits like "Fire and Rain," "You've Got a Friend," and "Carolina in My Mind"?

This cricketer, known as the "God of Cricket" in India, holds numerous records in both Test and One Day International (ODI) cricket, including the most runs scored and the most centuries. He was the first player to score 100 international centuries, a feat that cemented his legendary status. He played for India for over two decades, becoming a national icon and an inspiration to aspiring cricketers. Who is this Indian cricketer, widely regarded as one of the greatest batsmen of all time?

An army from what is now this modern­day nation attempted to invade the Joseon dynasty but was repelled by turtle ships. One general in this nation led "winter" and "summer" campaigns to try to capture his enemy's recently rebuilt castle. In 1281 this nation's defeat of the navy of Kublai Khan with the help of a typhoon was attributed to a "divine wind." The siege of Osaka occurred in this nation, which Tokugawa Ieyasu once led. Name this nation that on December 7th, 1941, bombed Pearl Harbor.

After a great storm, this man was marooned without supply on Jamaica for one year in 1503. Accusations of brutality such as cutting off a someone's ears and nose for stealing corn led to this man's imprisonment after a governorship. This man made contact with Arawak Indians on San Salvador, and his major discovery occurred during his voyage on the Nina, the Pinta, and the Santa Maria. Name this Genoan Mariner, credited with re­discovering the Americas in 1492.

A Lucas cell can be used to detect one element in this group that causes lung cancer. Ununoctium is the newest member of this group. Shorthand electron configurations features abbreviations for elements in this group in brackets. Each one of these elements is monatomic with a full valence shell. Name this group of unreactive elements on the far right of the periodic table, whose members include xenon, radon, and helium.

He's not Apollo, but this god sent a monster to ravage the land when King Laomedon (LAY-oh-me-don) didn't reward him for building the walls of Troy like promised. After being taunted by the hero Odysseus, Polyphemus prayed to this god, his father. This god lost a contest in which he created the first horse to Athena to become the patron god of Athens. Name this brother of Zeus and Hades, and god of the sea.

The highest point in this nation is Jebel Toubkal, and foreign enclaves surrounded by this nation include Melilla (meh-LEE-yah) and Ceuta (say-OO-tah). Its cities include Safi and Marrakech, and this country is home to the western terminus of the Atlas Mountains. It is north of the disputed Western Sahara and south of the Strait of Gibraltar. Name this country that includes the cities of Casablanca and Rabat.

Before amylase enzyme was isolated, this compound was used to turn corn starch into glucose syrup. The"fizz test" for calcium carbonate applies a muri-atic solution of this compound to rocks. Gold will dissolve in a mixture of nitric acid and this compound, called "aqua regia." Water and table salt are the products when this compound reacts with sodium hydroxide. Stomach acid consists of which strong acid with formula HCl [H-C-L]?

One of this author's works sees a scorpion bite Coyotito, the son of two pearl fishers, and in another novel, the knowledge that Cathy Ames was a prostitute drives her son, Aron Trask, to death. Besides many novels set in Salinas Valley, California, this author of The Pearl and Cannery Row wrote about how Muley Graves stays in Oklahoma while Jim Casey and Rose of Sharon run from the dust bowl with the Joad family. Name this American author of Great Depression-era novels like East of Eden and The Grapes of Wrath.

This documentary series, which has significantly increased the popularity of Formula 1 racing, provides an inside look at the drivers, teams, and rivalries that make up the sport. Its dramatic storytelling and behind-the-scenes access have attracted a new generation of fans. The series is produced by Netflix and has been praised for its ability to capture the intensity and excitement of Formula 1. What is the name of this show?

This desert is home to the Tibesti Mountains. The Tuareg people are indigenous to the central regions of this desert. This desert is bordered to the south by a region called the Sahel and also contains the cities of Niamey and Timbuktu. Sankore University was built by the Mali Empire on the edge of this desert. What largest hot desert in the world covers much of north Africa?

This singer-songwriter's music, often celebrating the beauty of nature and the simplicity of life, made him a prominent figure in the folk and country music scenes of the 1970s. His iconic song "Take Me Home, Country Roads," with its nostalgic lyrics and uplifting melody, has become an anthem for West Virginia and a beloved classic. His love for aviation led him to become an experienced pilot, a passion that tragically ended in his death in a plane crash. Who is this musician, known for his hits like "Rocky Mountain High," "Annie's Song," and "Leaving on a Jet Plane"?

Ukraine attacked this city with drones on the eve of discussions with the United States about their ongoing war. This city's iconic Red Square, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is home to St. Basil's Cathedral, a colorful and ornate structure with distinctive onion-shaped domes. Its metro system, known for its elaborate stations decorated with mosaics, sculptures, and chandeliers, is considered one of the most beautiful in the world. It is the political and economic center of Russia, and it has a rich history dating back to the 12th century. What is the name of this city, the capital of Russia, located on the Moskva River?

This man's donation founded the University of Chicago, the alma mater of his only son. This man once owned the companies that became ExxonMobil and Chevron, and he clashed with Andrew Carnegie. This man integrated his company both vertically and horizontally, leading to criticism from the muckraker Ida Tarbell. Name this "robber baron" who founded Standard Oil and whose grandson Nelson was vice president under Gerald Ford.

Early on in this conflict, the defensive "Maginot Line" completely failed to deter an invasion. In this conflict, the slogan "Work, Family, Fatherland" was adopted by a regime led by former war hero Philippe Petain. In this conflict, a French regime based in the city of Vichy (VEE-shee) was resisted by the "Free French". Name this conflict during which France was led by a Nazi puppet government.

A hypothetical type of this structure is the 20-mile long O'Neill cylinder, and Wernher von Braun's design for one is based on a rotating wheel. The most recently completed one of these is China's Tiangong-2. Valery Polyakov holds the endurance record for spending 437 days aboard one of these called Mir [meer], and due to a calculation error, the American one, Skylab, crashed in Australia upon re-entry. Name this type of structure whose International example houses astronauts and their experiments in outer space.

After this event, the Hotline Agreement was signed between its two major parties. This event was triggered in part by the photographing of bases at San Cristobal by a U-2 spy plane. As part of a compromise to resolve this event, the United States agreed to remove Jupiter missiles from Turkey, and during this event John F. Kennedy ordered the blockade of a Communist island. Name this 1962 Cold War incident in which the United States and Soviet Union stood on the brink of nuclear war.

This empire's "Great Interregnum" ended with the ascension of the House of Luxembourg. Local leaders of this empire met in the Imperial Diet. Within this empire, France rivaled the Hapsburgs for influence with its electors. This empire was ruled by Spanish kings in the 1500s after the election of Charles V. Name this fragmented Central European empire, which ruled much of medieval Germany.

This basketball legend's silhouette is the basis for the NBA's iconic logo, a testament to his impact on the sport. He was a 14-time NBA All-Star and won an NBA championship with the Los Angeles Lakers in 1972. He also served as a successful coach and executive in the NBA, showcasing his diverse contributions to the league. Who is this Hall of Fame guard, known for his clutch performances and his nickname, "Mr. Clutch"?

One crew member was missing after a vessel collided with a U.S.-flagged oil tanker in this body of water forcing the crews of both ships to abandon their vessels. This body of water, a shallow, epicontinental sea, is a major source of oil and natural gas for the surrounding countries. It is bordered by the United Kingdom, Norway, Denmark, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, and France. Its shipping lanes are some of the busiest in the world, connecting major European ports. What is the name of this sea, known for its strong winds and its role in European trade and energy production?

One novel by this author is about a thieving woman whose many husbands include a banker, a "Lancanshire" man, and her half-brother. Like Samuel Pepys, this author offered an account of the 1665 Plague in his A Journal of the Plague Year. Another novel follows a man who rescues a prisoner from cannibals. That prisoner is named Friday and the novel is narrated by a man stranded on an island for 28 years. Name this British author of Moll Flanders and Robinson Crusoe.

Reindeer Lake lies on the eastern border of this province and Lake Athabasca on the western border. Swift Current and Moose Jaw are to the south, and the Assiniboine River flows through the capital of this province. Bordered by the Northwest Territories to the north, Manitoba to the east, and Alberta to the west, this is what Canadian province whose cities include its provinicial capital, Regina, and Saskatoon?

This musician's bass playing, characterized by its melodic and inventive style, was a crucial element of The Beatles' groundbreaking sound. His songwriting partnership with John Lennon produced some of the most iconic and beloved songs in music history. He formed the band Wings after the breakup of The Beatles, achieving further success with hits like "Band on the Run" and "Live and Let Die." Who is this legendary musician, known for his prolific career as a singer, songwriter, and multi-instrumentalist?

This country is home to the second largest nickel reserves in the world, after Russia. An electric railway built by Hershey's chocolate company connects this country's capital to a province that contains the Zapata Swamp, Matanzas. The Hotel Nacional in this country's capital was home to a 1946 conference of organized crime leaders organized by Meyer Lansky. A United States military prison off the coast of this country has been the site of internationally condemned incidents of torture. Guantanamo Bay is off the coast of what Caribbean nation with capital at Havana?

This game show's format, created by Merv Griffin, features a unique answer-and-question format, where contestants are given clues in the form of answers and must phrase their responses in the form of a question. Its iconic host, Alex Trebek, hosted the show for 37 seasons, becoming a beloved figure in television. The show's categories cover a wide range of topics, from history and literature to science and pop culture. What is the name of this long-running game show, known for its intellectual challenge and its "Daily Double"?
incorrect3: Who Wants to Be a Millionaire

question: This basketball player is known for his clutch performances and his ability to hit game-winning shots. He played his entire 18-season career with the Indiana Pacers, becoming a beloved figure in the state. He was a five-time NBA All-Star and is considered one of the greatest three-point shooters of all time. Who is this Hall of Fame shooting guard, famous for his rivalry with the New York Knicks in the 1990s?

This leader went on the Great Embassy with his diplomats, and faced revolt from a group of guards supporting his brother Ivan V, the streltsy. This man's forces won at Poltava, beating Charles XII of Sweden in the Great Northern War. He forced nobles to shave their beards, simplified the Cyrillic alphabet, and moved the capital to a namesake port as part of reforms to Westernize his nation. Identify this modernizer of Russia, a "Great" czar.

This cultural and religious holiday, traditionally celebrated on March 17th, is associated with the color green, shamrocks, and leprechauns. It originated as a feast day for the patron saint of Ireland, who is credited with bringing Christianity to the country. It is now celebrated around the world with parades, Irish music, and dancing. What is the name of this holiday?

The cross-cousin form of this practice was common among the Iroquois. Under the Napoleonic Code, men could do this at age 18 and women at age 15. Obergefell v. Hodges was ruled in favor of same-sex couples being able to do this. Name this process, which usually involves a wedding ceremony.

Angular momentum is quantized as an integer multiple of the reduced form of this quantity, which is equal to this quantity over two pi and is denoted with a bar. The de Broglie ["de broy"] wavelength is equal to this quantity over momentum. The product of the standard deviations of position and momentum is at least this quantity over four pi by the Heisenberg uncertainty principle, and the energy of a photon is equal to this constant times the speed of light over wavelength. Give this constant, denoted lowercase h, named for a German founder of quantum theory.

The phrases ma non troppo and con moto may be appended to terms describing this property. Using rubato allows a performer to adjust this aspect of a piece. The terms accelerando and ritardando suggest a change in this musical property. A common term for marking this property of music, allegro, is typically realized at about 120 beats per minute. Name this term describing how fast or slow a musician should perform music.
